Well, I don't think there would be any great crisis or crashing ideas if the constitutional treaty was voted down.
Europe is operating as it is, at the moment, on the existing treaties, and could continue to do so for a while.
And it is possible that those treaties could, in themselves, be modified by parliamentary votes in the countries and that the EU would continue to function.

But the great hope of the constitutional treaty was that it would enable Europe to operate a lot more effectively, that it would create the post of a more permanent EU president, for example, who would serve for two and a half years and would be a better representative of the European Union; similarly, the creation of a foreign minister, and greater harmonization and integration in some other economic areas, and that the EU would work less well in the future, especially given that it has now gone from 15 to 25 members last year and could expand further with the addition of other members next year.
